Q65nRXGPOOYmMCERDqnmfw.text: advertises they're 24 hours, went there at 3am since we were stayin at the hotel and all the stations were closed down, there was a lady with an rbf at the noodles station saying she wasnt gonna serve food anymore. shoulda went to lau pat sat instead but it was pouring rain outside.

FzeY64-0LVTKq2OBP3gjjw.text: You'll always find a seat at this food court in MBS. Not a very big fan , however it is one of the only cheaper options within MBS.The one thing I tend to eat here is from the "Jia Xiang Kolo Mee" store. I always order the fried fish fillet mee - satisfying fragrant bouncy noodles topped with two large pieces of battered fish. That being said, the fish soup is very mediocre - stock is watery, noodles tasteless and the vegetables bitter ... don't eat it unless it's the only store that is still open.Another highlight from my visits. People manning the dessert / drinks stall are really rude... I ordered a cheng tng and forgot to tell them to take-away . It wasn't very crowded and when I tried to tell them to make it take-away, they started kicking up this big fuss and bitching about me to my face. Wow. Service A+ man. Oh yeah, and the cheng tng sucked anyway.

photos.caption: Photo of Rasapura Masters - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Rasapura Masters - Singapore, Singapore. CROWDS, CROWDS, CROWDS.

rfzKylSsCfhrnb8FHektHw.text: Here's a fun fact that few people know about: Rasapura is run by food court chain Koufu!I expected this food court to be jaw-droppingly expensive when I first visited, but it's actually not so bad. Granted, S$6.90 for a plate of char kway teow isn't exactly cheap, but for a fancy place in a fancy area, it's cheap in comparison. I was expecting nothing less than S$10, truth be told, and I'm glad that's not so.On to the food: you can find all the standard good court here: local stuff, Indian food, Malay food, Italian food, Jap food, and more. There's a sizeable dim sum stall, and I like selection over at the fruits and juices stall. The char kway teow I had was oily, but pretty good. Same goes for the Hokkien prawn noodles. The good in general is good, and the place not a shabby choice to dine in if you're looking for something more affordable in the area.There are lots of seats, which is great. I've always managed to find a seat in less than 10 minutes no matter how crowded it was. If it's more crowded than usual, you can grab some of the standing tables and get burn some fat as you pile on some more!

photos.caption: Photo of Rasapura Masters - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Rasapura Masters - Singapore, Singapore

QQhnOj2RDMpgze5TdtklzA.text: Bannok thai@ Rasapura foodcourtI thought that a food court at Marina bay sands charging $16 willHave good cust service...Rude and impatient! Like the rest of Singaporean f&b's

f0pE8W31JSQx-lMBNE0X4Q.text: So much choice!! The dim sum we're really good though always a line. Many good noodle dishes. Try it all!!Make sure to visit maxwell food center though as it has even more choice!

im9udXQN2HeJoCiDll7iWw.text: Some places at Rasapura are really very good and tasty - like hot beverages stall with traditional teas and kaya tost and there is great Korea food stall, nice Chinese dim sums and Indian food. On the other hand, Chicken rice - it's time for it to be renamed to Bones&Rice, same time they've removed from menu that great veg soup; and Nasi Padang - has very small and overpriced meat portions.

RFlv3dOg7sdAmtTLzvhJMA.text: i went here probably 4-5 times since we stayed at the MBSthere are plenty of food options.. it's a bit pricier than hawker stands.. but you get a cleaner and air conditioned environment.. the various noodle soups are awesome.. the hokkien mee noodle soup is fantasticnot all the stalls are opened 24/7..

BXToH0SqCUXNq-1Ienfreg.text: This is on the bottom level of the mall next to the skating rink. My wife ate from the Noodle Masters stall, which I would recommend. I ate the hokkien mee from the Singapore Noodles stall, which was bland so steer clear.

HSL_AMHLlKF83zBdcCIEaw.text: Tong Fong Fatt Hainanese Chicken rice: as sacrilegious as it might sounds found imthis place no less enjoyable than Tian Tian Chicken rice. Singapore proves foodcourts can be done well. Service and value are great for the Marina Sands venue. Repeat: only if in the Sands expo area.

clrWIzLrjFiJTOh4e9yBgQ.text: For the American in you, the Marina Bay Sands Hotel is the Hotel from the "Crazy Rich Asians" movie.  Expensive hotel that looks like a boat and has a futuristic up-scale mall adjacent to the Hotel and Casino.  This is a rating for the food court in the adjacent shopping complex.Indoor, Bottom Level, Air-Conditioned Food Court.Bright, Lots of Tables, Lots of Food Choices.  Close to 15+ food choices.Part of the Marina Bay Sands Shopping Complex, so you know it's going to be pricey compared to typical Hawker Stall Complexes that are not Air-Conditioned.These fast food places are not staffed by Client / Service oriented personnel.  One step above rude!Watch for up-selling and pay close attention to specials which are usually the best deals.  Incorrectly worded menu items causes much confusion!So after all that, we bought stuff from two shops:  Raspura Coffee and BBQ Chicken Wings.  Both lousy service.Raspura Coffee - Ipoh and Three Level Coffee, both sweet and rich,  pricey at $2 SGD and $3.20 SGD, respectively.BBQ Chicken -  Wings are 3 for $6.60 SGD and small Rojak Vegetarian at $6 SGD.  $2.20 for a scrawny, skinny chicken wing is not a good deal.  You have to buy a minimum of 3.Conclusion:  Nice, clean, modern, air conditioned, up-scale, relatively expensive compared to nearby Hawker Stalls.  Just rude people serving you.

photos.caption: Photo of Rasapura Masters - Singapore, Singapore. Coffee Choices La
Photo of Rasapura Masters - Singapore, Singapore. Coffeeeeeeee
Photo of Rasapura Masters - Singapore, Singapore. Chicken Wings and Rojak

8Ow4s6hAM1atB6FWLnxhyw.text: This review is for the dessert/drinks station. Do not come here!  So overpriced with hidden charges not even shown on the menu. When asked about where these charges are written in the menu, they say it's not! Got charged 9 dollars for a dragon fruit juice filled with water, got charged extra 2.50 for no ice and they didn't even finish the water juice to the top. Worst service experience in Singapore. Worst juicery experience worldwide.

photos.caption: Photo of Rasapura Masters - Singapore, Singapore. Charge extra 2.50 for no ice (not even posted on the menu! Be aware) they don't even fill the juice to top. Also diluted with a ton of water
Photo of Rasapura Masters - Singapore, Singapore. Don't buy drinks here. So overpriced with hidden charges not shown on the menu.

68I0KaQIUKF-wRgUqiGBDw.text: crowded food court for expo shops.  the hokkien mee just ok on flavor and wet sauce. LIM hainan chicken rice very good though.  juice ok.  currently under expansion

ofJVoC6e-qoS2mv_G-kqHA.text: Service: It was shit; the lady by the registers was so rude. 1/5Food: I got the fried bean curd roll and it was alright. It wasn't even warm, maybe lukewarm at best. I can get better food for less than half the price at hawker stalls. 1/5 Ambience: You are pretty much paying for ambience so of course it will be very nice. I like the marble tables and how the food court looks like an upscale hawker stall. 4/5

photos.caption: Photo of Rasapura Masters - Singapore, Singapore. Fried bean curd roll
Photo of Rasapura Masters - Singapore, Singapore. Fried bean curd roll

LZz53mCb_-G9WyuguO9Q4Q.text: I think given the many stalls of varying quality (from good to not so great), a 3 star is appropriate. I've had the char kway teow, which was actually rather disappointing since it wasn't that flavorful. The Satay stand on the other hand (Huat Huat BBQ), was solid. The dim sum stand on the other hand, had good soy milk but their BBQ pork buns were sitting in the steamer for WAY TOO LONG.  The bottoms of the buns were literally mushy because they were too saturated with water. It became like holding watery paste every time you grabbed the bun. So 3 star it is.

_JxTZKwhbn4MeM1jmVy_QQ.text: The Rasapura Masters food court is actually a quite nice food court despite the overall low ratings by some of the reviewers. It has most of the popular local (Singaporean/Malaysian) dishes.  Here's my personal rating for this place.Convenient:  It's super convenient for those who stay at the Marina Bay Sands hotel, which is awesome by the way.  About 3/5 stalls open 24 hours, so it's about the only place where you can get good food at wee hours. Vendor stalls:  There're 20 or so stalls so it will be quite hard for one not to be able to find something he/she likes.  But do keep in mind that this is mostly local type food, not Western type food so don't expect to find hamburger, fries, pasta, pizza, Steak, etc. here.  Service quality is mixed as some stalls have great customer service and some are pretty rude (like the ladies in the coffee/drink/deserts stalls)Quality of taste:  Though they're not the best when it comes to having the best dishes when compare to venders at some of the other hawker centers but the dishes here are not bad at all.  Some is not good but most are quite good and authentic. Quality of food is very good in terms of cleanliness with the exception of the HAKKA YONG TAU FOO stalk as both my mom and my wife got a bad case of diarrhea almost immediately after have a bowl of their noodle soup, on different days so I HIGHLY DON'T RECOMMEND this vendor.Cleanliness:  This place is super clean with very nice Marble tables and chairs.  There're Servicers' who come by often to clean up dirty dishes from tables.  This is about the only food court you'll find that doesn't have sticky tables.  But do bring your own napkins as they don't provide them.  In fact, most food courts and hawker centers do not provide napkins. Prices:  For the kind of food they serve, they're about 15-20% higher than any hawker centers throughout so they're not cheap. But given many of the benefits I noted above, 24 hr access, clean food, clean place, and convenient,  it is well worth it IMHO.  Beats having to hop on the MRT to hawker centers just to crave your hunger, especially late in the day. Overall, I recommend Rasapura Masters food court to those who stays or hang around the Marina Bay Sands hotel for its good food and convenience.  I would have given this a 5 stars but due to the bad experience of the HAKKA YONG TAU FOO vendor noted above, I gave this a 4 Star.

2934xtJzN9_Lv5QhGDBRuw.text: This food court can be overwhelming at first glance, but only because there are so many good food options! It was nice knowing that I could come here with my family and everyone could find something that they liked given the array of food stands and cuisine types. Generally, the area is clean with staff standing by to clear tables and pick up trash. Would definitely recommend this spot for a quick meal. This place is especially nice during the off hours as the crowd dies down significantly. I particularly liked the Noodle Star, which makes hand made noodles, the Hot Plate place which gives you sizzling meats and pepper rice on a hot stone plate, and the fruit stand that gives you fresh juices

photos.caption: Photo of Rasapura Masters - Singapore, Singapore. Noodle soup with hand made noodles from "Noodle Star"!

M6zsLxKr3QZTzAvzGOherQ.text: I went to 3 different food vendors here. The first upsold me something overpriced that I didn't want. The second asked what kind of meat I wanted and included ONE slice of meat. The third overcharged me until I spoke up about it then apologized. This place is looking to make a quick buck off of people who are not paying attention. The food is mediocre. Stick with the local food and avoid this touristy garbage.

dWl654ZzlwbyzsGhnDuDbg.text: The worst seafood I have ever had. $110 for the orders in the pictures. They taste like rubber bands and are not cleared. Don't try.

photos.caption: Photo of Rasapura Masters - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Rasapura Masters - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Rasapura Masters - Singapore, Singapore

7H6tV_HF-yAnSx0XyGZkQQ.text: The beef noodles was actually very good! I opted for small (= no soup) but portion of beef chunks was generous. The gravy for the dry version was savory and yummy!

boh3cS-VdmLFSeeZOCZwng.text: Pretty decent food court in the MBS shopping mall. Good variety of options and neat and clean as well. I tried the Malay Mutton curry which was very good.

R9o0I_r_bVFvpbbhN9ozeQ.text: I must say, I have a general interest for food courts outside of my own city.  This one is in the Shoppes at Marina Bay Sands (which is probably a must if you're a tourist). I like the idea of getting whatever I want and of him getting whatever he wants - and we both share a fast and casual meal or snack. I never took note of the names of the food stalls we grabbed food from, but food was good.  I got three pieces of a meat dumpling wrapped around a million times with crispy stuff.  My description is so bizarre but if you take a look at the picture, you'll know what I mean!  This was pretty good, made nicely, would have tasted better with hot sauce.  My partner got a couple plates from, I think, a Singaporean food stall.  He got popiah (wrap) and kueh pie tee (crispy cup).  Both were good as well.  Did not blast us with flavour but was a nice snack not leaving you feel too heavy. Not much to say about service as it's a food court, but tables and area were super clean and not that busy when we went during the off-hour.  Not a HUGE food court but you will likely find something to your tastes :)

photos.caption: Photo of Rasapura Masters - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Rasapura Masters - Singapore, Singapore

r3BRtQo9zAgA8eHZPM6vdg.text: I always like to check out food courts in foreign countries. In my opinion, this is much higher quality than your typical food court fare. I actually ate there twice, as the selections were good, the prices reasonable, and the location at the bottom level of marina bay sands mall, convenient. I had chicken and rice that was really really good..my wife had fish soup that she thought was too "fishy" but once she added some spices it was better. I thought the iced coffee and iced milk tea at one of the stalls was amazing and helped overcome the jet lag blues. We didn't test it out but a few of the stands are supposed to be open 24 hours which would be nice when your mental clock wakes you up at 3am.

photos.caption: Photo of Rasapura Masters - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Rasapura Masters - Singapore, Singapore. Chicken and rice

SvPvM64Uw9qjsrvTtSe7jA.text: BS this place, fkn rip off the old lady. I came to the counter to order and quickly she came and ask what I want to eat. I asked for the two piece deep Fried charsui set (one order) and one piece deep fried shrimp. She quickly pulled two sets of charsui order and one three piece deep fried shrimp set PLUS and extra piece. This totaled me 11.50 rather than spending $6 something. I asked only wanted one order each, but got ignored and wanted to quickly charge my food. Had no choice I guess since it was already in my face and the cashier ringed the price. Seems like they like rip off tourist. I see locals here ordering food and I didn't see that old lady rushing towards them and up selling them. Eff you for the wonderful first time experience in visiting Singapore.

zUPpJzMuWlL-z52f5mhzBA.text: Not all food places are open 24 hrs.  Only a handful are open at 7am.The food variety is amazing!  From fresh hand made noodles made to order to dimsum, Mexican food, Japanese food, pizza etc.  This is a food lover's one stop shop!We had some traditional Singaporean noodles and also the fresh hand made noodles.  Both very fresh and tasty!  My only complaint was the heat in the dining area.  I know most places in Asia are like that but for someone that was only in town for two days and was not yet used to the heat and humidity...I wanted to pass out!  People are like ants!  They are everywhere!  No personal space.  I have to say, here in America we are a bit spoiled.  This was around lunch time, for breakfast it was definitely a much more pleasant experience.

photos.caption: Photo of Rasapura Masters - Singapore, Singapore. Dimsum station
Photo of Rasapura Masters - Singapore, Singapore. Food court by ice skating rink

i9oEudZNDQPcRet6-TMoPQ.text: This is a really expensive food court. It is a glorified version of food republic in terms of price but with lackluster food. Even Glutton's Bay, a 15 min walk from here, offers much tastier delights at lower prices. Of course, there are some decent selections if you have eaten here often enough to know what to look for but for most, it is more likely to be a miss than a hit.What you are really paying for is the convenience and comfort of dining in an air-conditioned setting at a casino. While there will always be people raving about this place (it is arguably a good place for price insensitive tourists to enjoy a wide variety of Singapore food), locals should definitely look elsewhere.Overhyped and overpriced. Not shiok at all lor.

9kauxvys_7IZlqb6JJ3riA.text: plenty of options at this food court.. on a crowded day/time could get tricky to find a table and also to find your way back to the aforementioned table after ordering food. We had some chicken and fish from the Italian joint, very fresh, hot and quite affordable.

oI2a_bLdqIbKDeusPfBSnA.text: Okay, so firstly, I hate mall food. Gross! Sick! Maybe I'm just conditioned to dislike foods that's served in malls in America. So sue me! (McDonald's, Panda Express, chik-fil-a, the list goes on BARF!) Anyhow, we headed over to the shopping mall because we couldn't check into our hotel. Hungry, tired from traveling 24 hours,  and with time to kill, we stumbled upon this "fancy" (fancy for a food court) food court. This was truly a gem. This is not a separate food court stall section, this food court is all owned by the same company. With so many options as far as delectables went. They had dim sum, peaking duck, suckling big, fried rices, noodles, chicken and rice, juices, you name it they probably had it. We decided to go with a variety of dim sum, 3 shrimp har gow, 3 chicken and scallion dumping, 3 pork buns, and 3 sesame peanut balls (1 order is a serving of 3, you must pay for 3) . Loved every last bit of it!! Best of all it costed us around $10 US dollars total! We were definitely full, and was more than enough. We actually loved this place so much we came back, after we tried a bit more pricy dim sum place in the mall, and it still wasn't as good as our cheap food court dim sum. Actually, we ate as KU DÈ TÀ, because we felt the need to treat ourselves to a nice dinner, and it honestly still wasn't as good as here and the hawker centre. (NOTE: just go for the cheap food in Singapore, you're not missing out on anything!!!!!)

P1NZAlAbc1V0dQNLiB7TcA.text: Rasapura Masters is nothing but an overpriced mall food court. Commercialized versions of local dishes that completely lack character and cost three times as much as hawker stalls. Total tourist trap.
